title: Acute Chest Pain in Emergency Department
description: 70-year-old woman presents with chest pain - classic NSTEMI presentation

personality.emotionalState: fearful and worried it's her heart
personality.communicationStyle: detailed answers, asks clarifying questions, wants reassurance

history.hpi: Patient reports substernal chest pressure that started 2 hours ago while gardening. Describes it as 'heavy feeling, like an elephant sitting on my chest.' Pain radiates to left arm and jaw. Associated with mild shortness of breath and nausea. Tried antacids with no relief. Denies palpitations or loss of consciousness.
history.familyHistory: Father had heart attack at age 62, mother has diabetes

socialHistory.smoking: Former smoker, quit 5 years ago, 20 pack-year history
socialHistory.livingSituation: Lives with husband, two adult children nearby

general.level1: Anxious-appearing woman in mild distress, holding chest
general.level2: Anxious woman in moderate distress, diaphoretic, pale
general.level3: Ill-appearing woman in significant distress, diaphoretic, clutching chest

cardiovascular.level1: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Pulses equal bilaterally.
cardiovascular.level2: Tachycardic, regular rhythm, no murmurs. Capillary refill <2 seconds.
cardiovascular.level3: Tachycardic, possible S4 gallop, JVD present. Peripheral pulses intact but weak.

respiratory.level1: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles
respiratory.level3: Bilateral basilar crackles, increased work of breathing

abdominal.level1: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, normal bowel sounds
abdominal.level2: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, normal bowel sounds
abdominal.level3: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, normal bowel sounds

Chest X-ray.level1: No acute cardiopulmonary process. Normal heart size.
Chest X-ray.level2: Mild cardiomegaly. No infiltrates or effusions.
Chest X-ray.level3: Cardiomegaly with pulmonary vascular congestion. Small bilateral pleural effusions.

ekg.level1: Sinus rhythm, rate 88. ST segment depression in leads V3-V6 (1mm). No acute ST elevation.
ekg.level2: Sinus tachycardia, rate 102. ST depression in leads II, III, aVF, V4-V6 (1-2mm). T wave inversions in V3-V5.
ekg.level3: Sinus tachycardia, rate 115. Widespread ST depression (2-3mm). Deep T wave inversions anterolaterally. Possible acute coronary syndrome pattern.

changes.symptoms: Patient reports pain worsening from 7/10 to 9/10
changes.emotionalState: increasingly anxious, asking 'Am I going to die?'

changes.patientResponse: Thank you, doctor. I do feel a bit better.
The pressure is easing up a bit.

redFlags.consequence: Increased risk of mortality and myocardial damage
Delayed intervention for acute coronary syndrome

deterioration.newSymptoms: Patient becomes hypotensive, chest pain 10/10, severe dyspnea

patientCannotSay: I think I'm having a heart attack
This could be a pulmonary embolism
customRules: Patient is educated but not medically trained - uses layperson terms
Patient can express fear about heart problems but not diagnose
Patient may ask 'Is this my heart?' but cannot state specific conditions
